rest.sentence: The heterointerfaces of charge-selective contacts are crucial in determining efficiency and stability of perovskite optoelectronic devices, where the fundamental knowledge of the buried heterointerface between perovskite and bottom charge transport layer is less well understood compared to the top interface

Herein, we systematically investigate the energetics at the perovskite/SnO2 buried heterointerface for an n-i-p perovskite solar cell  and the perovskite/PEDOT:PSS buried heterointerface for a p-i-n one, respectively

In contrast to previous cognitions, we discover a perovskite transition phase at the buried interface region that originates from the chemical bonding interaction with the bottom charge transport layer
The transition phase causes an energy level barrier and induces defects, impeding charge transport across the heterointerface
These detrimental effects trigger significant nonradiative recombination and limit the attainable device photovoltage
We then develop the energetic models that describe such buried heterointerfaces
Moreover, we further test the proposed model-derived mechanisms via inserting a thin polyvinyl alcohol layer into the buried heterointerfaces of the devices

We demonstrate that chemical interactions and formation of the perovskite transition phase at the buried heterointerface thereby are fully restrained, leading to a diminished electron extraction barrier and improved charge transport
As a result, significant increases in open-circuit voltage and fill factor of the devices are achieved
These results will help guide future efforts on developing suitable buried heterointerfaces for superior performance of perovskite optoelectronics.
Download : Download high-res image Download : Download full-size image
Solution-processed metal halide perovskites have gained great success in optoelectronic devices,

Perovskite solar cells  have achieved skyrocketed increase in power conversion efficiency  from 3.9% to now 25.7% over the last few years, attributed to effective material refining, defect passivation and interface design,

For conventional n-i-p  architectural PSCs, a polycrystalline perovskite semiconductor film is deposited on an underlying electron  transport layer with an opposite hole  transport layer coated on the top surface ,

The created heterointerfaces between the perovskite and charge transport layers have been demonstrated to be important sources for nonradiative carrier recombination, resulting in a large gap to devices operating at their full thermodynamic efficiency, .
In a typical PSC, the energetics across the heterointerfaces between perovskite and charge transport layers, e.g

the relative positions of the perovskite’s valence or conduction bands and the charge transport layer’s frontier energy levels, i.e., highest occupied molecular orbital  and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital  levels, largely determine charge extraction and thus device output efficiency,

In particular, contrary to a flat band at the interface, the charge transfer at the heterointerfaces commonly causes an abrupt step in vacuum level  often termed interface dipole, or extended space-charge regions frequently referred to as band bending, or both
These energetic behaviors beyond all doubt impact on the charge transport dynamics at the heterointerfaces
Hence, the perovskite heterointerface of charge-selective contacts have been critical in boosting PSC efficiency and stability with recent remarkable progress, .

However, most research efforts have been focused on the heterointerface between perovskite and the top charge transport layer to vastly improve its interface engineering, whereas the buried heterointerface of the perovskite layer with the bottom charge transport layer has received less attention because of its non-exposed features and difficulties in methodology to explore it nondestructively
This is unfortunate as the buried interface is at least as important as the top interface in PSCs
The recent works by Huang et al., Zhu et al
and Thomas et al

all found that the buried perovskite heterointerfaces suffer more morphological voids, higher sub-microscale extended imperfections and defect concentrations than that of the top perovskite heterointerface, which have opened the door to use imbedded additives to reconstruct the bottom of the perovskite film for ulteriorly suppressing device energy loss and operational degradation,
Nevertheless, knowledge of the energetics at the perovskite buried heterointerface in PSCs is largely lacking so far

To reliably guide the development of perovskite optoelectronic devices, it is thus highly desirable to obtain insights into the energetics at the buried perovskite heterointerface with the bottom charge transport layer, and their effects on device optoelectronic properties.
In this work, we successfully uncover the energetics at the buried heterointerface between perovskite and the bottom charge transport layer for n-i-p and p-i-n structural PSCs, respectively
The evolution of such heterointerface properties and their effect on device performance are monitored in detail

In contrast to previous cognitions, a perovskite transition phase is formed at the buried heterointerface region, originating from the appearance of chemical bonding with the bottom charge transport layer
This causes an increase of the interface energy level barrier and induces defects, thus impeding charge transport across the heterointerface
In addition, we find that charge-extraction-impeding band bending occurs at the buried heterointerfaces
We then develop the energetic models that describe such buried heterointerfaces
Moreover, we validate the proposed model-derived mechanisms via insertion of a polyvinyl alcohol  thin layer into the buried heterointerface in PSCs

The open-circuit voltage  and fill factor  are remarkably enhanced with the elimination of interface chemical interactions and thereby reduced electron extraction energy barrier that boost charge transport across the buried heterojunction
This work provides insights into the perovskite buried heterointerface and sheds lights on further interface design to enhance efficiency and stability of perovskite optoelectronic devices.

To intuitively estimate the impact of the perovskite buried heterointerface on device performance, we firstly fabricate two common PSCs with an n-i-p structure of ITO/SnO2/MAPbI3/Spiro-OMeTAD/MoO3/Ag and a p-i-n structure of ITO/PEDOT:PSS/MAPbI3/PCBM/BCP/Ag for comparison , respectively
The current density-voltage  characteristics show that the n-i-p device delivers a typical PCE of 18.42% with a Voc of 1.08 V and a short current density  of 23.56 mA cm−2, while the p-i-n
Lead iodide , lead bromide , and cesium iodide , bisimide lithium , tertbutylpyridine , poly:poly  and Poly[bis amine]  were purchased from Polymer Light Technology
Tin oxide  colloid precursor  was received from J&K Scientific
Methylammonium iodide , formamidinium iodide

The work is supported by the National Science Foundation of China grant , the National Key Research and Development Program of China , Shanghai Science and Technology Innovation Action Plan , the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities, and East China Normal University  Multifunctional Platform for Innovation
also thanks the project funded by China Postdoctoral Science Foundation  and ECNUS.X
Shaobing Xiong is currently a postdoc in Institute of Optoelectronics at Fudan University
He received his BS in Physics from Soochow University in 2017 and PhD from East China Normal University in 2022 under the supervision of Prof
His research focuses on perovskite solar cells.Qinye Bao

Due to the unpredictable composition and vulnerable nature of the grain boundaries , grain boundaries engineering with improving the order degree of perovskite GBs would be the breakthrough for high-performance polycrystalline perovskite solar cells
However, there are rare works on the stacking structures of passivators and on their influence on performance
Herein, based on the easily aggregate nature, a bicarbazole molecule featuring cyanogroup was used as a GB passivator to self-assemble ordered porous framework structures in GBs
The formation of pores depends on the inversion of the carbazole plane

Besides defect passivation, humidity barrier and crystallization promotion abilities, the ordered porous stacking structure shows extra advantages on lead leakage elimination and tensile stress relief

The easily deformable quadrilateral pores, which are connected by weak forces with adjustable bond length, give the skeleton a function of “turning joint” that releases tensile stresses during the thermal process by its structural expansion, and thus, restricting perovskite expansion with ion migration/evaporation suppression, which is commendable for passivators
As a result, a champion PCE of 23.15% is realized, and PSCs show significantly enhanced thermal and operational stability, as well as diminished lead leakage
This work reveals more possibilities in grain boundary engineering and provides a new avenue for stable and environmental-friendly PSCs.

Wide-bandgap perovskite is considered an ideal absorber for the top component cell of a tandem configuration, in addition to having proven advantageous for indoor light conversion and semitransparent solar cells
In this work, we demonstrate an ambient aging process that appears to further raise the performance of wide-bandgap perovskite solar cells
Systematic study shows that that secondary recrystallization arises during the aging process
The defect density is further attenuated by air passivation and the self-healing effect induced by halogen redistribution
As such, the nonradiative recombination in the perovskite films is suppressed, and the carrier lifetime is prolonged during the ambient aging

The champion wide-bandgap  perovskite solar cell delivered a power-conversion efficiency as high as 20.12%, coupled with a high open-circuit voltage of 1.27 V, which is among the highest values reported for this type of wide-bandgap solar cells

This work reveals the impact of the air aging process on the properties of perovskite films from various aspects and demonstrates a scalable post-treatment strategy capable of producing state-of-the-art semiconducting films.

Flexible perovskite solar cells are new energy devices with a promising future due to their numerous advantages, such as high defect tolerance, strong solar absorption and low non-radiative carrier recombination rates
However, their operational stability is still an ongoing challenge during upgrading, and their inferior moisture corrosion resistance is still a major issue for better performances

Thin-film encapsulation could effectively enhance the operational stability of perovskite solar cells but obtaining encapsulation films with excellent barrier performance always come at the expense of poor flexibility
Therefore, the development of novel encapsulation materials with both barrier performance and flexibility is urgent for the compatibility of flexible applications

In this work, "Plasma-Enhanced Molecular Layer Deposition" was used for the first time to prepare a highly cross-linked, densified flexible encapsulation material AlOC at 40 ℃ to break through the traditional technology
The resulting encapsulation material can be applied to flexible perovskite solar cells as a barrier film without any damage

The as-obtained encapsulation film exhibited a water vapor transmittance rate of 1.44 × 10−5 g m−2 day−1 and preserved 95 % of its initial barrier performance after 10,000 bends with a 3 mm bend radius
Such performance was the best among the reported thin-film encapsulation layers of flexible perovskite solar cells.

Nickel oxide  is a prospective hole transporting layer  material for inverted  perovskite solar cells ; however, inevitable surface defects on the NiOx surface interfere with the realization of high-performance PSCs
Herein, nickel nitrate is used to eliminate defect sites and hydroxyl groups on the NiOx surface
For the first time, it is found that a uniform and ultra-thin nickel nitride  layer can be formed on the NiOx surface through the spin coating of the nickel nitrate solution at low temperatures

Promisingly, this new approach allows to overcome interface losses originating from defect sites and hydroxyl groups on the NiOx surface and to achieve high efficiency and long-term operational stability in PSCs
Furthermore, NixN serves better energy level alignment between NiOx HTL and perovskite layer, resulting in improved charge extraction and transportation and reduced charge recombination

The NixN-modified NiOx-based PSC demonstrates an outstanding efficiency of 20.45% and it shows long-term operational stability about 82% of the initial efficiency after 1000 h under ambient air conditions
Thus, this simple approach using nickel nitrate can be a promising and universal strategy to revive nickel oxide-perovskite interfaces and boost the performance and operational stability of PSCs.

The carrier non-radiative recombination loss caused by numerous interfacial defects existing between perovskite and neighboring charge transport layers, such as SnO2/perovskite and perovskite/spiro-OMeTAD, which greatly restricts the performance improvement of flexible perovskite solar cells

Herein, we devised a novel dual-modification strategy using Ce-containing compounds 3 and Ce2) to minimize interfacial defect density at the interface of SnO2/perovskite and perovskite/spiro-OMeTAD respectively, thus enhancing the performance and stability of flexible PSCs
It was revealed that the introduction of Ce23 interface layer was conducive to ameliorating the electrical properties of SnO2 and significantly reducing the SnO2/perovskite interface defects

Moreover, the Ce2 was adopted as a novel oxidant to achieve the rapid oxidation of spiro-OMeTAD, thus enhancing the hole mobility of bulk spiro-OMeTAD and suppressing perovskite/spiro-OMeTAD interface defects
Therefore, reduced non-radiative recombination losses near the two interfaces of the perovskite layer could be achieved by such a novel and comprehensive modification strategy
In consequence, the Ce-modified flexible and rigid PSCs achieved excellent photoelectric conversion efficiency  of 19.34 % and 22.62 %, respectively
Notably, the optimized flexible PSCs exhibited outstanding mechanical durability, and 83.2 % of the initial PCE was maintained after 3000 bending cycles.
Excess PbI2 can improve the efficiency of perovskite solar cells
However, it usually leads to poor cell stability due to the chemically active nature of PbI2
Improving the stability of PbI2-rich perovskite solar cells without scarifying the efficiency remains challenging
In this work, it is found that the non-uniform and multiple nucleation of perovskite induces crystallographic disorders at grain boundaries  of PbI2-rich perovskite
These disorders working as the n-type shallow dopant reduces the energy barrier for photogenerated electrons to reach GBs, triggering the decomposition of excess PbI2 there
Therefore, the instability of PbI2-rich PSCs is related with the remote coupling of excess PbI2 with the disorders at GBs

In light of this finding, we introduced a small amount  of CdI2 into precursor solution to optimize the crystallization of PbI2-rich perovskite, and finally achieved a trade-off between efficiency and stability in PbI2-rich PSCs
The optimized PSCs with 10 mol% excess PbI2  achieved a champion efficiency of 24.26% at the bandgap 1.55 eV with robust stability

PC-Devices maintain more than 90% of the initial efficiency after being stressed under UV light in ambient with a relative humidity of 50% for 500 h, and 70% under heat at 85˚C for 400 h, both of which are far superior to the pristine PbI2-rich solar cells.
Shaobing Xiong is currently a postdoc in Institute of Optoelectronics at Fudan University
He received his BS in Physics from Soochow University in 2017 and PhD from East China Normal University in 2022 under the supervision of Prof
His research focuses on perovskite solar cells.Qinye Bao
Sheng Jiang received his MS in Materials Science and Engineering from Nanchang University in 2021
He is currently a PhD student under Prof
Qinye Bao’s supervision at East China Normal University
His research focuses on perovskite solar cells.
Yefan Zhang received his BS from Soochow University in 2020
Now he is a PhD student at Soochow University
His work focuses on organic photovoltaic cells.
Zhiwei Lv is currently a MS student at East China Normal University
His research focuses on semiconductor defects.
Ruirong Bai is currently a PhD student at East China Normal University
His current research is on materials for photovoltaic and photonics applications.
Yuting Yan is currently a MS student at School of Physics and Electronic Science, East China Normal University
Her research focuses on the phase transition of single crystals under high pressure.
Qi Zeng received her PhD in Condensed Matter Physics from Fudan University in 2015
Then she went to Linköping University as a postdoc
In 2018 she joined Shanghai University of Engineering Science
Her research focuses on organic- and perovskite-based devices.
Xionghu Xu received his BS in Applied Physics from Donghua University in 2019
He is currently a PhD student at East China Normal University
His research focuses on the phase-change materials.
Liming Ding got his PhD from University of Science and Technology of China
He started his research on OSCs and PLEDs in Olle Inganäs Lab in 1998
Later on, he worked at National Center for Polymer Research, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base and Argonne National Lab
He joined Konarka as a Senior Scientist in 2008
In 2010, he joined National Center for Nanoscience and Technology as a full professor
His research focuses on innovative materials and devices.
Yuning Wu received his BS in Physics from University of Science and Technology of China in 2006 and PhD in Physics from University of Florida in 2012
Currently he works in Department of Electronics at East China Normal University
His research focuses on the defect physics of semiconductors.
Xianjie Liu received his B.S
in physics from Lanzhou University in 1993 and Ph.D
in physics from Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Science, Technical University of Dresden in 2003
Currently he works in Surface Physics and Chemistry Division at Linköping University
His research interests focus on the investigation of organic materials by synchrotron-based spectroscopies upon their electronic and structural properties and their applications on organic devices.
Mats Fahlman received his M.S
in Engineering Physics  and Ph.D
in Surface Physics and Chemistry  from Linköping University, where he is currently a full professor at the Laboratory of Organic Electronics
He is active in the research of organic semiconductors using primarily surface science techniques to explore materials and interfaces as well as their effect on device properties.
Qinye Bao is currently a professor in School of Physics and Electronic Science at East China Normal University
He received his Ph.D
in 2015 in Surface Physics and Chemistry from Linköping University

The focus of his work is on surface science techniques, such as ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and near edge X-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy, to reveal the relationship between interface electronic structures and device performance, especially for application in organic solar cells, organic light-emitting diodes, and perovskite-based optoelectronic devices.
